articles.headline: Grumbles Follow Plan to Raise Bank Capital
articles.snippet: A proposal that very large banks maintain 6 percent leverage ratios, twice the ratio that smaller banks are supposed to meet, has drawn the usual complaints.
articles.abstract: A proposal that very large banks maintain 6 percent leverage ratios, twice the ratio that smaller banks are supposed to meet, has drawn the usual complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the years just after the financial crisis — 2010 and 2011 — large American and European banks took drastically different courses. American banks raised a lot of capital. Many of the European ones did not.

articles.headline: Mandela’s Kin Face Gray Area on End of Life
articles.snippet: Medical experts say Nelson Mandela, the stricken South African icon, is probably being sustained by equipment, which could present his relatives, doctors and the country with a painful choice.
articles.abstract: Medical experts say Nelson Mandela, the stricken South African icon, is probably being sustained by equipment, which could present his relatives, doctors and the country with a painful choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The family of Nelson Mandela, who has been lying at the edge of death in a South African hospital for more than a month, might in the days or weeks to come face the same awful decision that has confronted numerous other families in an age of life-sustaining miracle machines: when is it time to say “enough.”

articles.headline: Consumer Frugality Adds to Woes in France
articles.snippet: As seen at the sprawling Marché aux Puces, Paris’s most famous flea market, concerns are growing for France’s economic health in the near future.
articles.abstract: As seen at the sprawling Marché aux Puces, Paris’s most famous flea market, concerns are growing for France’s economic health in the near future.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a recent Sunday at the sprawling Marché aux Puces de St. Ouen, France’s largest and most famous flea market, crystal chandeliers glinted in a rare patch of Parisian sun.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Taps Speechmaking Gold Mine
articles.snippet: The events are giving Hillary Rodham Clinton large captive crowds as she considers a run for president in 2016.
articles.abstract: The events are giving Hillary Rodham Clinton large captive crowds as she considers a run for president in 2016.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few months after leaving the State Department, Hillary Rodham Clinton has plunged into the lucrative world of paid speechmaking, joining a branch of the family business that has brought the Clintons more than $100 million since her husband left the White House in 2001.

articles.headline: Leaner BP Blanches at Bill for Cleanup
articles.snippet: The oil company told a federal appeals court that a claims administrator misinterpreted the terms of a multibillion-dollar settlement reached last year.
articles.abstract: The oil company told a federal appeals court that a claims administrator misinterpreted the terms of a multibillion-dollar settlement reached last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Three years after its disastrous oil rig accident in the Gulf of Mexico, BP has managed to strengthen its finances by divesting itself of less profitable operations, ramping up new oil production in the North Sea and Angola and reducing its exposure to volatile investments in Russia.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: With Royal Baby Due in Britain, Street Is a Waiting Zone
articles.snippet: No due date has ever been made public for the birth of Prince William and Kate Middleton’s first child, but that hasn’t stopped crowds from forming outside St. Mary’s hospital.
articles.abstract: No due date has ever been made public for the birth of Prince William and Kate Middleton’s first child, but that hasn’t stopped crowds from forming outside St. Mary’s hospital.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Waiting around for someone else to give birth can be a slow and tedious marathon of an experience. But for the photographers and cameramen on royal baby-watch outside St. Mary’s Hospital in Paddington, the monotony has entered another stratosphere entirely.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Pressing Latin Americans to Reject Snowden
articles.snippet: The United States is conducting a diplomatic full-court press to try to block Edward J. Snowden from finding refuge in Latin America.
articles.abstract: The United States is conducting a diplomatic full-court press to try to block Edward J. Snowden from finding refuge in Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The United States is conducting a diplomatic full-court press to try to block Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American intelligence contractor, from finding refuge in Latin America, where three left-leaning governments that make defying Washington a hallmark of their foreign policies have publicly vowed to take him in.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Randal C. Archibold

articles.headline: Snowden Renews Plea for Moscow to Grant Asylum
articles.snippet: After weeks of silence, the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden appealed for help in gaining asylum in Russia as he continued to seek passage to Latin America.
articles.abstract: After weeks of silence, the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden appealed for help in gaining asylum in Russia as he continued to seek passage to Latin America.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a high-profile spectacle that had the hallmarks of a Kremlin-approved event, Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive American intelligence contractor, broke his silence after three weeks of seclusion on Friday, telling a handpicked group of Russian public figures that he hoped to receive political asylum in Russia.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Andrew Roth
